pullRequest.body:
We define a type class `Finset.HasAntidiagonal A` which contains a function
`antidiagonal : A → Finset (A × A)` such that `antidiagonal n`
is the Finset of all pairs adding to `n`, as witnessed by `mem_antidiagonal`.

When `A` is a canonically ordered add monoid with locally finite order
this typeclass can be instantiated with `Finset.antidiagonalOfLocallyFinite`.
This applies in particular when `A` is `ℕ`, more generally or `σ →₀ ℕ`,
or even `ι →₀ A`  under the additional assumption `OrderedSub A`
that make it a canonically ordered add monoid.
(In fact, we would just need an `AddMonoid` with a compatible order,
finite `Iic`, such that if `a + b = n`, then `a, b ≤ n`,
and any finiteness condition would be OK.)

For computational reasons it is better to manually provide instances for `ℕ`
and `σ →₀ ℕ`, to avoid quadratic runtime performance.
These instances are provided as `Finset.Nat.instHasAntidiagonal` and `Finsupp.instHasAntidiagonal`.
This is why `Finset.antidiagonalOfLocallyFinite` is an `abbrev` and not an `instance`.

This definition does not exactly match with that of `Multiset.antidiagonal`
defined in `Mathlib.Data.Multiset.Antidiagonal`, because of the multiplicities.
Indeed, by counting multiplicities, `Multiset α` is equivalent to `α →₀ ℕ`,
but `Finset.antidiagonal` and `Multiset.antidiagonal` will return different objects.
For example, for `s : Multiset ℕ := {0,0,0}`, `Multiset.antidiagonal s` has 8 elements
but `Finset.antidiagonal s` has only 4.

```lean
def s : Multiset ℕ := {0, 0, 0}
#eval (Finset.antidiagonal s).card -- 4
#eval Multiset.card (Multiset.antidiagonal s) -- 8
```

## TODO

* Define `HasMulAntidiagonal` (for monoids).
  For `PNat`, we will recover the set of divisors of a strictly positive integer.

This closes #7917

Co-authored by: María Inés de Frutos-Fernández <mariaines.dff@gmail.com>
and Eric Wieser <efw27@cam.ac.uk>

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go

-->

nodes.body:
> Looking again, it would probably makes sense to put the `antidiagonal` and `piAntidiagonal` parts of this work in separate PRs; it looks like the former alone would result in a lot of deduplication.

We'll do that, but the core of our PR was `piAntidiagonal`…
should the prefix `Finset.Nat` of docs#Finset.Nat.antidiagonal_succ  be changed to something else? `Finset.natAntidiagonal_succ`?  (that would be painful to change all this)

> should the prefix `Finset.Nat` of docs#Finset.Nat.antidiagonal_succ be changed to something else? `Finset.natAntidiagonal_succ`? (that would be painful to change all this)

I think leaving those lemmas where they are for now is fine. In a later PR, we could reame them to `Nat.finsetAntidiagonal_succ`, which I think is consistent with where we have the lemmas about `Finset.Icc` on `Nat`.

Note: I have pushed an update to the lean toolchain because this PR was on a [buggy version](https://leanprover.zulipchat.com/#narrow/stream/113488-general/topic/Potential.20data.20loss.20from.20.60lake.20clean.60.20with.204.2E2.2E0-rc2.2F3/near/397875701) of the toolchain. **WARNING**: checking out old commits of this PR using v4.2.0-rc2 or v4.2.0-rc3 can cause `lake clean` to delete your mathlib folder! If you need to do so, make sure to delete `lakefile.olean` manually before running any `lake` commands.
If I understand correctly, you managed to prove lemmas about docs#Nat.Antidiagonal in the generality of docs#HasAntidiagonal.
Yes; but more than that, I merged the `Finsupp` and `Nat` versions of many of the lemmas.
@AntoineChambert-Loir This PR seems to be converging. Could you please update the commit message of the PR (in the topmost post)?
@jcommelin , I updated the initial blurb of the commit (just a copy-paste of what is on top of the file).

Thanks :tada:

bors merge

Looking again, it would probably makes sense to put the `antidiagonal` and `piAntidiagonal` parts of this work in separate PRs; it looks like the former alone would result in a lot of deduplication.

Should we have a `HasAntidiagonal` typeclass? That would allow us to have a O(n) rather than O(n^2) implementation, and I can see this being executed / reduced in combinatorics.

What types `μ` do we care about in practice?

1. For the `HasAntidiagonal` typeclass. Yes, gladly, if that allows to have a faster implementation, but I don't know what to change exactly.

2. We will use for a type`μ` the type of finitely supported functions from some type to Nat.

To be precise, we will use piAntidiagonal to express the coefficients of the products of power series and prove some results such as : if a power series as a nilpotent coefficient as constant term, then its powers converge to 0 in a strong sense (= simple convergence on coefficients, discrete topology on the target, meaning than each coefficient of f ^ n is eventually 0 when n goes to infinity)

````suggestion
```lean
def s : Multiset ℕ := {0, 0, 0}
#eval (Finset.antidiagonal s).card -- 4
#eval Multiset.card (Multiset.antidiagonal s) -- 8
```
````
Why are you referencing the mathlib3 file? We have this fine in mathlib4, it's https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/blob/master/Archive/Wiedijk100Theorems/Partition.lean.
(because we didn't know it was in mathlib4)
I think you should remove this comment entirely, and replace `cut` with your new definition!
You mean, in the Archive file ?
Yes!

I did that, but there was a conflict of the decidable instances. I managed to pass through, but this is ugly and  I don't believe we wish to leave that as is.
(In presence of `hf : f in piAntidiagonal s n` with bad decidable instances, I added `suffices : hf' : f in piAntidiagonal s n`, which has the good instances and which  I proved using `convert hf`.
I could adjust the Archive file using piAntidiagonal.

```suggestion
  /-- The antidiagonal function -/
  antidiagonal : μ → Finset (μ × μ)
  /-- A pair belongs to `antidiagonal n` iff the product of its components is equal to `n` -/
  mem_antidiagonal : ∀ (n : μ) (a : μ × μ), a ∈ antidiagonal n ↔ a.fst * a.snd = n
```
OK. I thought the parentheses were part of the notation.
I think probably this should live in the `Finset` namespace, given your comments about multiplicity.
Done

Here's how this becomes restated using the new typeclasses:
```suggestion
/-- In a canonically ordered add monoid, the antidiagonal can be constructed by filtering.

Note that this is not an instance, as for some times a more efficient algorithm is available. -/
abbrev antidiagonalOfLocallyFinite : HasAntidiagonal μ :=
  antidiagonal n := Finset.filter (fun uv => uv.fst + uv.snd = n) (Finset.product (Iic n) (Iic n))
  mem_antidiagonal n := sorry
```
at end of line 73, is it `:=` or `where`?
that required a lot of prefixes `antidiagonalOfLocallyFinite` later on, but that worked.
Here you should be taking `[HasAntidiagonal μ]` instead of relying on a specific instance.
yep, and at two other places below as well!

`export 
```suggestion

export HasAntidiagonal (antidiagonal mem_antidiagonal)
```
to allow access to the short names

This should instead be:

* A `Subsingleton (HasAntidiagonal u)` instance
* Replacing `nat.antidiagonal` with `instance : HasAntidiagonal ℕ`

I did that, but I have two questions :
* for the moment, this instance (and the one for Finsupp.HasAntidiagonal) are in their respective files ; maybe they should belong to Mathlib.Data.Finset.Antidiagonal
* My use of the Subsingleton instance is probably awkward
I think they're best in their respective files.

This one should be an `instance`, and it should be *instead* of the `antidiagonal` definition above. The idea here is to unify all the antidiagonals under a single function name (the one from the typeclass).
A question : `mem_antidiagonal` was tagged with `@[simp]`. How do restore this behaviour?
`attribute [simp] mem_antidiagonal` immediately after the `export` line
Note that after you make the typeclass change above, you'll be able to revert all of these, as there will be no `Nat.antidiagonal`.
This can now be removed entirely, I think the subsingleton instance alone is enough.

```suggestion
  mem_antidiagonal {n : μ} {a : μ × μ} : a ∈ antidiagonal n ↔ a.fst * a.snd = n
```
which matches the explicitness of the existing `Nat` lemma, and should make the diff smaller at the call sites as a result
Oh, I guess I meant to comment this on `HasAntidiagonal` below.

This is either going to cause a clash, or be ignored. I'd suggest you drop this multiplicative version from this PR to prevent it growing too much, and leave a TODO comment instead that references something about divisors and PNat.
I removed the multiplicative version

```suggestion
  mem_antidiagonal {n : μ} {a : μ × μ} : a ∈ antidiagonal n ↔ a.fst + a.snd = n
```
done now (I had done it only on HasMulAntidiagonal…)
`open Finset (antidiagonal)` on the line above would save the need to add namespacing here.
I assume all the changes to this file can be reverted too?
not all the changes. I'm sorry I forgot do to that.
I can push a fix if you like
you were faster than me anyway…
I pushed a change that made `mem_antidiagonal` a `simp` lemma (to match the `Nat.mem_antidiagonal` it replaced), so you should be able to remove all the changes of this form
what is simp[..., *] ?
I don't know how to detect them, anyway.
I suspect this might not be needed any more
Well, `rfl` doesn't work for proving this lemma.
While it is true that after the `change` and `rw`, `cong!` concludes (but relatively slowly).
This lemma looks useless to me
I deleted it.
This probably isn't all that useful, `congr!` can solve it.
Indeed!
I think there's some duplication in this paragraph.
I changed it slightly.

Overeager Ctrl + F?
```
where the `n`-th term is a sum over all pairs `(k, l)` such that `k+l=n`, which corresponds to
`Finset.antidiagonal n`. -/
```

Same here
```suggestion
    expressed by summing on `Finset.antidiagonal`.
```

```suggestion
is the finset of all pairs adding to `n`, as witnessed by `mem_antidiagonal`.
```
